author: François-René Rideau
title: AVOUM: Account View on UTXO Model
description: DeFi smart contracts that anyone can interact with are subject to "DoS" attacks by constantly racing other participants to the current UTXO.

assessments.note: This proposal tackles the murky water of real transactions, mixing the discrete with the indeterminate reality of transaction in the real world.  This provides a foundation for protection of transactions against bots.

The proposer fails to recognize that Cardano was purposely built for the eUTXO instead of the Ethereum Accounts style and that the eUTXO model allows you to parallelize/thread multiple contracts at once that sync up at a later time, thus eliminating the race to singe utxo issue they highlight here. Trying to rebuild Ethereum accounts on top of Cardano's eUTXO instead of building the correct design patterns/contract structures required to mitigate this a poor allocation of Catalyst funds.

The problem statement in this proposal is simply false (and thus this entire proposal becomes moot). "DeFi smart contracts that anyone can interact with are subject to "DoS" attacks" is not at all true in Cardano's Plutus model since developers can scale their dApp by deploying multiple versions of the same contract and using a state-thread token to track/sync state across the contracts. This means that not only is DOS attack an unrealistic risk vector, it means the smart contract can actually scale to meet the demand of a large user base. Nowhere in the proposal does the author mention this as it ruins there narrative that UTXO needs an account view, it does not, and the devs at IOHK have made it clear how Plutus contracts can be constructed to mitigate the "race to the UTXO" problem.

The proposal also conflates the Ethereum transaction mempool process with Cardano's which is another fatal flaw since these are vastly different
As the proposer stated, this proposal meets the challenge in a roundabout way, by removing a problem which could render many DeFi solutions vulnerable to manipulation.

The statement of the problem and solution are reasonable and are aligned with the challenge. The proposal has positive impact potential, not only in smart contracts related to DeFi but also in smart contracts related to NFTs. The deliverables described could be used by Defi and NFTs projects as an important infrastructure to improve quality and safety of protocols / dapps.

You do not need an Accounts model to make Cardano DeFi operate at scale. There are several solutions to the UTXO spend per block and the proposal fails to mention any of them. Why would IOHK develop a smart contract platform for 5 years that does not scale/is susceptible to DOS attacks? This is never answered or made clear in this proposal.

This proposal is not effectively addressing the challenge of building a DeFi protocol on Cardano's Plutus layer. You don't need an accounts model on Plutus there are teams that have built entire concurrent state management proof of concepts that make this proposal's problem statement entirely moot, if anything this is a distraction from the f5 challenge.

It's false to assert Cardano requires an accounts model to avoid DOS attacks, the proposer either does not fully understand UTxO's or is being somewhat intellectually dishonest in the problem statement/solution.

The information presented in this proposal is super misleading in the context of UTxO and DOS attacks. There are several solutions to the problem presented and the proposer does not mention any of them. This is not effectively addressing the challenge.

A proposal to not build a DeFi protocol on Cardano but instead rebuild Ethereum's broken accounts model is not at all addressing the f5 Defi focused challenge. The proposer does not articulate any of the ways Plutus teams are building solutions to address this known UTxO tradeoff today, there are several already in the works.
The race on contract is a real risk for DeFi, sometimes even reported as a hack by the media. This proposal addressed the problem with a framework to avoid it.

The skills and experience of the team is fantastic, but the risk is in whether or not the cardano language would support these types of contracts. given that the team recognizes the risk and proposes an alternative solution in the proposal the team shows that they have experience and know what they're up against.

There is no detailed development plan or KPIs included in the presented info. MuKn is the team behind Glow, a DSL, Plutus and the eUTXO model of Cardano is a general purpose, Turing-complete language, these are very different domains.

The team behind this proposal is working on Glow but their experience working on UTXO vs. Accounts model is not made evident, they also make false claims in the problem statement and proposal plan that make validating their experience on this proposal even less compelling.
Proposers have a good idea of what they are trying to do. There is a risk of failure in development as they still seem to have parts to work out.

The team presented link to their GitLab, where it is possible to check the code developed by MUKN. They have been working with Blockchain scaling solutions for 3 years, and have successfully launched the dapp language Glow in partnership with IOG. I recommend including links to LinkedIn of the people involved in the development of the proposal.

Despite the complexity of the problem and the proposal, there is an extremely articulated and structured rationale. There is an objective plan described in Step 1.

Deliverables are good indicators of success. There is a simple and objective timeline, within the application for this challenge.

Risks for delays in the Alonzo HFC were considered and there is a plan for development in the future.

The team's experience in Accounts vs. eUTXO accounting models is not made clear. The proposal also fails to mention the Plutus design patterns DeFi teams may use as a workaround to the UTXO 'race' described in the proposal.

The proposal team does not have seem to have an expert view on Cardano's eUTXO model. They don't mention any of the solutions currently being developed to handle multiple contract instances that render their entire prob statement/solution to problem moot.

The team behind this proposal is building Glow, this does not give them any experience in the DeFi space or in the ability to properly analyze Accounts vs. UTxO models. Given the lack of experience and since the plan presented does not at all mention the mitigations that exist (running several contracts and syncing the UTxO state) it's unclear why this proposal is needed.
The team behind this proposal does not fully understand how the Plutus eUTxO model works in Cardano or the solutions built to manage smart contract instances at scale.

The entire plan presented is centered around the thesis UTxO based dApps are susceptible to DOS attacks, this is not true and the several teams building Plutus protocols are all working on various scaling solutions to enable their sc architecture to function at scale. The proposer mentioned none of these.
The open-source code given as example shows good coding practices and demonstrate coding skills both in Solidity and Plutus.
The proposal shares how feasible the solution is and offers an alternative way to achieve the desired results.

The proposer fails to recognize Cardano is 1. purpose built using the eUTXO model and 2. design patterns already exist to mitigate the single UTXO spend per block issue which is the focal point of the entire proposal. Rebuilding Ethereum accounting on top of Cardano is a poor idea.

As noted above, their are false statements in the problem statement and in the proposal plan that make the proposers experience *and the need for an accounts view model* highly questionable. Does this proposer really think IOHK Plutus devs are naïve enough to spend the last 5 years on a contract model and not build in a plan to mitigate DOS attacks because that's essentially how this proposal reads. It's simply not true and it shows they have either 1. spent little time understanding how the Plutus eUTXO model actually works or 2. Is conflating Ethereum accounts model/contract design pattern with Cardano. both of these blatant issues makes this proposal a non-starter.
Reasonably detailed proposal and plan allowing auditing of success.

There is clarity in the description of the problem. The described solution addresses the problem and challenge.

There are details on budget allocation, there is a link to the team repository, but I recommend more detailing on the team members' experiences. Add a link to members LinkedIn allows the community to have access to more information about the team's qualifications easily and transparently.

There are reasonable deliverables. There is a clear and objective timeline. No KPIs were described.

This proposal is not at all required for Cardano DeFi, the eUTXO Plutus model can work at scale and IOHK Plutus devs have spoken on several developer calls on how these design patterns can be safely implemented in DeFi protocols on Cardano

The proposal fails to make it clear *why* the Plutus concurrent state management solutions are not sufficient for teams building DeFi dApps on Cardano. They dont even mention this, leading CA's to believe this proposer team has a very limited understanding of how the Plutus eUTxO model actually works.
Rebuilding eth's accounts model on Cardano is not the answer to scaling Cardano's DeFi ecosystem.

This proposal is essentially an attempt to rebuild the Ethereum accounts model on Cardano's eUTxO but they completely ignore the fact IOHK purpose built Cardano's UTxO to *not be* the same accounting model as Ethereum and there are several known ways to handle several sc instances that enable DeFi dApps to operate at scale.

The information provided is not sufficient and this proposal draws away from the true purpose of this challenge which is to fund teams delivering Plutus Defi protocols on Cardano in the next 6 months.

solution: We solve issue by offering an "Account" view on top of the UTXO model of Cardano, using malleable transactions and Node-Extractable Value.
experience: We have been in the space of blockchain scaling for 3 years, and have successfully launched the DApp language Glow with IOHK as partner.
